text.headline: A Changing Boyle Heights
text.text: Increasing rents is not a new story for L.A. But are new developments meeting the needs of the community? Who is getting pushed out and how? Where are they going? KPCC looks at stories past and present in a neighborhood that has resisted gentrification, but is seeing new developments pop up all over town.

text.headline: Whittier Boulevard and Hollins Street
text.text: Elvira Barrales has lived in her rent-controlled Boyle Heights apartment for 16 years with her four children. In April she received notice that two of her children needed to go under threat of eviction. She fought her eviction notice in court and won. Meanwhile, KPCC saw the same property is listing apartments on Craigslist as “art district adjacent” for $1,000 per month compared to Barrales' $630 per month. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: industrial Street
text.text: This is where LA realtors hoped to guide house hunters on a bike tour around the neighborhood in 2014. They distributed flyers that said “Why Rent Downtown When You Could Own in Boyle Heights?” Neighbors shut it down. The bike tour was cancelled and the real estate agency apologized, but the community was clearly stirred. One person wrote on Twitter “It's been fun watching #BoyleHeights rally around the most tone-deaf gentri-flyer in the history of man today.” Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: Olympic boulevard and Soto street
text.text: An 11-story Sears Roebuck store stood tall in Boyle Heights since the 1920s until it closed. Developers are now creating a mixed residential, retail and office space. Boyle Heights residents criticized the new development’s lack of affordable housing. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: Mariachi Plaza
text.text: Mariachi Plaza in Boyle Heights is a local landmark, known for generations of musicians waiting for gigs. Metro owns the land and wants to develop the area adjacent to the Plaza. Plans for retail and medical office space were tossed out after residents objected, and now Metro is taking suggestions from the community. Everything from grocery stores to a Mariachi museum has been suggested. The musicians fear that more could cause the traditions and soul of Mariachi Plaza to be lost. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: Proyecto Jardín
text.text: Since January, members of the Boyle Heights community have been conducting a 24/7 sit-in to keep a cultural spot under their care. Proyecto Jardin is a community garden on land owned by White Memorial Medical Center. When the garden’s lease was up, White Memorial did not want to extend the lease on the terms they had with the garden managers for 15 years, wanting to change things, including the name from Proyecto Jardin to White Memorial Memorial Garden. “For many of us, it's indicative of sort of devaluing our culture and all of the sweat equity, the time, the work, the effort that's been made to turn that into a space that's inviting," one activist said. This is an ongoing case between activists resisting the loss of their garden and the medical center. Read the full story at kpcc.org.

text.headline: Carnitas Michoacan No. 3
text.text: For 33 years, Carnitas Michoacan was the 24-hour neighborhood go-to spot after church or when everything else was closed. Unlike the unwavering certainty that Carnitas always provided for 2 a.m. nachos and tacos, for Orlando Orta, who has worked there for 27 years — and other employees —  the future is less clear. The restaurant is closing down and will be replaced with a Panda Express, eliminating yet another Boyle Heights institution and leaving all its employees to join the workforce again.

text.headline: First Street Studios
text.text: Local artist Lilia Ramirez has lived in Boyle Heights for almost 20 years. She opened First Street Studios in 2007. Even though she rented the space, she renovated the space, charging them to her credit card. The studios featured local artists and was a space for community members to organize. Ramirez left in 2010 when she saw fancier spaces popping up around First Street. Outside investors took over her old space, which now rents for nearly double the $1600 Ramirez paid monthly for the 1,800 square foot space. She is still paying off the renovations.

text.headline: 1st and Soto street
text.text: When Ramirez first moved to Boyle Heights, she lived where the Soto metro is now. She moved around, until settling in a single-family house with three other people, where she has lived for almost 8 years. They pay about $1600 a month to rent the four bedroom, two bath house. Her home is one of about 15 households who will have to relocate to make room for a East LA Community Corporation affordable housing project called El Cielito Lindo. She and her neighbors organized for a guaranteed right of return once the project is complete, but first they have to find housing for the next two years while the new structure is being built.

text.headline: East Cesar E. Chavez Avenue And Brittania Street
text.text: Robert Avila lived in a duplex with his mother, Aurora, who lived on the property for about 50 years. They both have fought back four different eviction attempts between September 2014 and February 2016. For one of those attempts, Robert was unaware that his $520 rent was due on a holiday. He sent the check in but it bounced because the money hadn’t yet been transferred. He wasn’t aware of this until he received a five day eviction notice five days later, the day he was supposed to be out. When he tried to pay it in person, they wouldn’t accept. The landlord claimed that they gave him this notice on time, but Robert won the court battle and has lived there since. He said similar “scare tactics” have been used on his neighbors, and they end up leaving because they never fight back.

text.headline: 1st and Cumming Street
text.text: Founded in 2009, Corazon del Pueblo describes itself online as “a volunteer-run, not-for-profit collective, and community cultural center.” The grassroots organization had to leave their location on 1st Street in 2014 due to rising rents. “It was a place where people could come, connect, and share,” said long-time Boyle Heights resident Erick Huerta of the community space.
